title: Withholding loans near the Sabbatical year
vignette: As the Shemitah year approaches, a creditor debates whether to extend a loan he may never collect.

options.text: Refuse the loan; protect your assets.
Lend anyway, trusting the release command.

title: Writing a *prozbul* to bypass debt release
vignette: A creditor can file a legal instrument that keeps debts collectible despite Shemitah.

options.text: File the prozbul; retain the right to collect.
Do not file; allow the debt to be cancelled.

title: Debtor repays voluntarily after Shemitah
vignette: Post-Shemitah, a debtor asks whether to repay even though the debt was legally cancelled.

options.text: Repay out of moral duty.
Keep the money; the law released you.

title: Commercial sale of Sabbatical-year produce
vignette: A farmer considers selling large quantities of Shemitah fruit for profit.

options.text: Sell freely; income sustains your family.
Limit to small, symbolic sales or give away.

title: Fencing an orchard during Shemitah
vignette: Landowner debates locking his orchard to protect crops or leaving it open for all.

options.text: Fence it; safeguard produce and trees.
Leave it open; let anyone pick freely.

title: Hoarding produce after the *biʾur* deadline
vignette: Shemitah fruit is no longer available in the wild; may a family keep stores at home?

options.text: Keep it; private stock is your right.
Remove or distribute it as required.

title: Trading Shemitah produce for higher-value goods
vignette: Person exchanges holy fruit for superior produce, pocketing the gain.

options.text: Trade; maximise value within legal bounds.
Avoid trade; consume it in its original form.

title: Bartering produce for money and passing on sanctity
vignette: Seller converts Shemitah wine into cash, transferring its sanctity to the coins.

options.text: Use the cash for ordinary purchases.
Spend it only on items eaten with the same sanctity.

title: Feeding sacred produce to animals
vignette: Left-over Sabbatical greens could feed household animals though still fit for people.

options.text: Give them to the animals; nothing wasted.
Reserve for human consumption only.

title: Leasing a field to a non-Jew to permit cultivation
vignette: Owner considers renting farmland to a gentile so work continues during Shemitah.

options.text: Lease it; maintain income stream.
Refuse; preserve the land’s mandated rest.

title: Paying wages with Shemitah produce
vignette: A land-owner wants to hire labourers to harvest ownerless seventh-year fruit and pay them with that same produce.

options.text: Permitted – payment in kind is fair and keeps costs down.
Forbidden – Shemitah produce may not be used as a wage commodity.

title: Selling by measure or by estimate
vignette: Merchants wish to sell Sabbatical oranges by exact weight, not by loose handfuls, to satisfy urban customers.

options.text: Allow precise weighing – ensures honest trade.
Prohibit weighing; only informal measures keep commerce modest.

title: Feeding sacred produce to non-Jews
vignette: Household has surplus Shemitah greens. May they give them to a Gentile neighbour’s animals?

options.text: Yes; better use than waste.
No; holy food is for Jewish consumption only.
